item.title: If a thing is worth doing
item.description: There’s the old saying, “If a thing is worth doing, it’s worth doing well.” I, like many of you, was raised on this saying and others like it. “If you’re going to do a job, do it right the first time.” That was another of my mom’s favorites. These sayings are aiming at doing good work rather than sloppy careless efforts. If I’m going to clean the kitchen, do a good job wiping off the counters, getting the toast crumbs under the toaster, and cleaning out the sink.

item.title: The philosophy of the newspaper
item.description: Introduction Philosophy and …newspapers!? What could these two totally unrelated things possibly have in common except being antiquated and therefore something I’m bound to be interested in? Well, in this post I’ll tell you what I’ve discovered after weeks of intense research about the newspaper: the industry, the product, and the why behind it all (that’s where the philosophy comes in!). If you stick around till the end, I’ll layout what I think are the keys to using philosophy and some modern adaptations to revitalize the newspaper industry, and perhaps a sense of local community with it.

item.title: What's up with Up?
item.description: The meaning of lines A horizontal line is sensed as “being at rest, just as the human body is at rest when horizontal. They give a sense of stability, balance, and tranquility.”1 A vertical line is sensed as “one of aspiration, reaching, assertiveness”2. Instead of the restful equilibrium you see with horizontal lines, we get a dynamic equilibrium. There are forces held in check, just like a human body standing takes lots of muscles to keep it upright, or the strength of a tree’s roots holding the tree against the wind.

item.title: Love, cheese, and dead French philosophers
item.description: I’ve picked up reading Blaise Pascal’s Pensées lately and this statement made me wonder: “The greater the intellect one has, the more originality one finds in men. Ordinary persons find no difference between men.”1 Do you agree? Intelligence corresponds with an ability to see, perceive, and find things. And not just regular objects, but qualities such as uniqueness, originality, and worth. Failing to see difference in men could mean one is more prone to prejudice and bias.

item.title: Marginal Strangeness vs. Total Strangeness
item.description: At least 4.6 billion1 people believe they will live on after they die. They believe that somewhere, somehow, their spirit, soul, or essence will persist beyond the grave. However mystical the process, life after death is not a strange idea to them. In fact it is quite familiar and perhaps comforting. But to that same group the idea of reincarnation – of living again in a different human or animal body – that idea sounds too strange to take seriously.

item.title: Why I Recommend Philosophy
Human Free Will is a Qualitative Reality
item.description: A year ago, free will was freedom to do what I wish. Eating a bowl of delicious honey nut cherrios now or later. Wearing the button down shirt I wore yesterday that doesn’t smell bad or a fresh one. Also, to decide who I will be, my attitudes, my priorities. To be the captain of my soul. That fullness of ability I often neglect yet that can still inspire me. That was free will.

item.title: How The Mental Models of Orienteering and Topographic Thinking Can Help Us Understand The World
item.description: Introduction Recently, I picked up an old college textbook I’d saved, thinking someday I’d peruse its pages and maybe get interested in Biology again. Well, the other day I finally did. While reading the introduction, two mental models stood out to me: the mental models of Orienteering and Topographic Thinking. In this piece, I’m going to relate these two models as my professor taught them, and then perhaps in later posts extend it to other concepts and writers.

item.title: Don't be upgraded
item.description: Technology offers an interesting set of verbs almost daily: “Upgrade”, “Sign in”, “Create Account”, “Buy”, “Activate”, and “Download” to name a few off the top of my head. item.title: Questions to be lived
item.description: Not often, but sometimes, you stumble upon a question that is so profound to you that you would almost be sad to find the answer. It keeps you searching yourself, calling upon something deeper than rote learning or textbook memorization. Perhaps we can call these “floating questions.” They evade scientific explanation. Floating questions demand an answer from your life. They can generate enormous passion, send humans into space, and create beautiful art.

item.title: Have a good day, Have a good life
item.description: One golden afternoon last October, while taking a walk, I wrote a thought down: “Eventually, my life will just be as good as my days. So I need to enjoy my days if I am going to enjoy my life.” Embedded in there is the idea that no one state or achievement will likely “make” my life. Instead of some grandiose event, life’s quality is subject to more prosaic influences like the quality of our relationships, sleep, self-talk, hobbies, and food.

item.title: Article 13
item.description: Article #13: Is there any value in the Past? Objection 1: It seems there is little value to the past because opportunity for action lies in the present. Since we cannot act in the past, and our purpose is to act rightly in this world, our focus should be on the present. The past holds lessons and data from which we may draw as required to meet our current needs, but the value of the past is defined only by its usefulness to the present and future.

item.title: Moderation in moderation
item.description: There are special times in life to go all out. Last year, I went all out on a 50-mile hike alone, completing it in 19 hours. I learned some invaluable lessons like Don’t trust Google maps over mountains (I got lost) Always pack an extra almond poppyseed muffin. Stopping to rest only makes your legs hurt more. More importantly, I learned that after being alone and exhausted for hours, all the noise in your head quiets down, and you come to know yourself and your limits.

item.title: No Quality Exists in Isolation
item.description: If conduct matters at all, if we can say there are good actions and bad ones, then there must exist an objective value – an impersonal external system of moral truths that transcend changing human minds and changing material things - that qualifies our judgment of ‘goodness’. It is objective in the sense that it does not depend on our opinion or feelings about it for its being. To speak or think of goodness or lack thereof requires thinking in qualities.

item.title: Plato, the moral revolutionary
item.description: Almost 2400 years ago, one of the greatest revolutions the western world has ever known set off. It was a relatively quiet explosion, not a famous battle or the overthrow of an empire. It was a young man watching his hero, teacher, and mentor put on trial and condemned to death. His teacher had dedicated his life to questioning others, for, as he put it, “the unexamined life is not worth living.

item.title: Small Talk as an Onramp
item.description: As an introvert, small talk has never come easy for me. I enjoy watching the occasional football or basketball game.
